item.title: System Hardening
item.description: System Hardening is the process of securing a system’s configuration and settings to reduce IT vulnerability and the possibility of being compromised. To safeguard the data, services we need to secure our Linux system. The article presents detail on linux system hardening, step by step. Update software and kernel Make sure that the system is up to date. yum update -y Enable firewall See the section firewall for detail Remove unnecessary package and users Some services are installed and enabled by default, we may not use.

item.title: NTP
item.description: NTP is an internet protocol that’s used to synchronise the clocks on computer networks to within a few milliseconds of universal coordinated time (UTC). Chronyd is a daemon for synchronisation of the system clock. It can synchronise the clock with NTP servers, reference clocks and manual input using wristwatch and keyboard via chronyc. It can also operate as an NTPv4 server andpeer to provide a time service to other computers in the network.

item.title: Redis
item.description: In-memory data structure store, used as database cache and message broker. In-memory database is a database that keeps the whole database in RAM. Supports data structure such as strings, hashes. list, sets, sorted sets. Each time you query a database or update data in a database, you only access the main memory Redis-cli Following are the helpful redis command Check redis file configuration redis-server /etc/redis.conf login to Redis server host 10.

item.title: Mailcleaner Basic
item.description: Basic Terminology MailCleaner is an anti spam gateway installed between your mail infrastructure and the Internet. MailCleaner is built on popular and very efficient free software OS: Debian 8 Jessie, MTA: Exim, Filtering: MailScanner, Anti-Spam: SpamAssassin, Anti-Virus: ClamAV, Web GUI: Apache/PHP/mysql. Following are the terminology frequently used in mailcleaner or any other mail filtering gateways:- Virus / Antivirus An email virus consists of malicious code that is distributed in email messages, and it can be activated when a user clicks on a link in an email message, opens an email attachment or interacts in some other way with the infected email message.

item.title: SNMP
item.description: Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) is a way for different devices on a network to share information helps in communication of devices of different hardware and software. It is a protocol used by network management tools to identify devices, monitor network performance, keep track of changes to the network, or determine the status of network devices in real time. It works on client-server model. Network manager collect and process information about devices on the network.

item.title: SPF
item.description: Sender Policy Framework (SPF) is authentication protocol used to indicate to mail exchanges which hosts are authorized to send mail for a domain. It is defined using TXT record type, also has SPF record type. If you send email from xyz.com to tecnep.com, tecnep.com mail server will check if xyz.com is authorized for sending email or not. item.title: DKIM
item.description: Domain Key Identified Mail is email authentication technique that allows the receiver to check that an email was indeed sent and authorized by the owner of that domain. It is email security standard designed to make sure message weren’t altered in transist between the sending and receipient servers by the use of private and public key cryptography. How DKIM works ? a) On sender mail server A hash is created from the content of the message headers and signed it with private key.

item.title: DMARC
item.description: Domain-based Message Authentication Reporting and conformance (DMARC) is designed to protect your company’s email domain for being used for email spoofing, phishing scans. It is enhancement to existing email authentication technologies. DMARC uses existing two protocols SPF and DKIM and applies the policy for receiving email. Record is published in DNS record to specify which mechanism (DKIM, SPF or both) is employed when sending email from that domain, how to check ‘From:’ field of the sender email.

item.title: Firewall
item.description: Firewalld provides a dynamically managed firewall with support for network/firewall zones to define the trust level of network connections or interfaces. firewalld provides support for zones, predefined services and ICMP types and has a separation of runtime and permanent configuration options. Permanent configuration is loaded from XML files in /usr/lib/firewalld or /etc/firewalld Install firewall in centos yum install firewalld -y Start the service systemctl start firewalld Enable the service systemctl enable firewalld Add tcp port 443 to listen https traffic
